page.title: 11Cotswold Stone Quarrying (2)
page.content: There is a layer of blue clay all over the Cotswolds. Between this and the silica lies Pendle stone which is used for slates. The clay is water-tight and a lake of one hectare is being made at Huntsmans Quarry. Water from this is pumped to the stone-washing machinery. Dirty water is pumped away to a slime pit. There is a borehole 90 metres deep which provides domestic water at the quarry for the adjacent farm and the 20 employees during their 8-hour working day. 20 separate specifications of material can be produced e.g. granular sub-base materials for road construction, various types of single-size stone chippings. Distribution is generally within a radius of 3 km. Exceptions include fine dust to Bargoed, S.Wales and walling stone to Manchester.
